subject: Fix build + delete races
commit_message:
Fix build + delete races

Nova should always try to unprovision and just fall through if Ironic
tells it that the node is already unprovisioned. Combined with the fact
that nova will retry on 409s, this will resolve any race conditions with
builds and deletes:

An unprovision while Ironic is deploying will result in a 409 HTTP
Conflict. Once the deploy finishes, the unprovision will go through
after nova retries a number of times.

This also does allow concurrent unprovision requests to Ironic, but this is
okay. The 2nd one will 409 because ironic has an outstanding task on the
node and keep retrying until the first one completes. At that point,
nova will get a BadRequest and move on because the node was
already unprovisioned.

Also: We should make the scheduler skip any nodes that have a
provision_state while there's no instance_uuid assigned. This
probably means something bad has happened, so let's treat it as if
the node is in maintenance mode.

Change-Id: I8960dec7c610f7bc5cfcfdbcc1c6b2527c1ca388
Closes-bug: 1337461

subject: Fix bug with some OS options not being passed to client
commit_message:
Fix bug with some OS options not being passed to client

Fixes a regression that is preventing swiftclient from
authenticating using keystone v3 options.

swiftclient/shell.py processes the dict of command
line options to set up a child dict ('os_options')
of keystone auth specific options (line 960). The
processing includes stripping --os- prefixes from
the command line options before adding keys to
os_options.

A recent patch https://review.openstack.org/#/c/85453/
introduced a duplication of this option processing
in service.py (line 79) which replaces the os_options
created in shell.py, but omits keystone v3 related
options. Consequently the keystone v3 options are
not being passed to the client get_auth() method.

This patch adds the keystone v3 related options to
the option processing in service.py.

For pragmatic reasons (i.e. fixing the bug quickly)
the option processing code has not been removed from
parse_args in shell.py. It is likely that the code in
parse_args is now redundant, but all code paths between
parse_args and process_options should be inspected and
test coverage added before removing that code.

Unit tests have been added in test_shell.py to verify
that command line options are correctly passed to the
client get_auth method.

The MockHttpTest class is re-used in test_shell.py,
so it is moved from test_swiftclient.py
to tests/unit/utils.py

Closes-bug: #1372465

commit_message:
VMware: Remove host argument to ds_util.get_datastore()

Since the removal of the ESX driver, we no longer pass host to
ds_util.get_datastore(), and we always pass a cluster. This change
removes the host argument, and assumes we always get a cluster.

This is a relatively simple change, but it has 2 knock-on effects to
tests. Firstly, almost all tests using get_datastore were passing host
and cluster as None, None, which excercised a code path which only
made a single vim call. This meant that passing in
fake.FakeObjectRetrievalSession() worked well. That code path was
removed (because it was never actually called), and the new code path
makes either 2 or 3 vim calls. This requires more complex faking of
vim calls, which we do in _mock_get_datastore_calls(). Note that this
is only faking the vim calls, so we're still testing get_datastore,
not the fake function.

The second knock-on effect is to the incredibly fragile
test_spawn_mask_block_device_info_password in test_vmops. This test
has to allow enough of spawn() to run to generate a debug log message,
as it is testing that log message. This change caused an irrelevant
exception to be raised in _get_vm_config_info, which prevented it
getting as far as the log message. We poke the test a bit so it
doesn't break any more.

Finally, we entirely remove test_get_datastore_no_host_in_cluster
because:

1. the previous code did 'if datastore_ret:' so returning '' and None,
   as returned by test_get_datastore_without_datastore, were

subject: Reject overly-taxing ranged-GET requests
commit_message:
Reject overly-taxing ranged-GET requests

RFC 7233 says that servers MAY reject egregious range-GET requests
such as requests with hundreds of ranges, requests with non-ascending
ranges, and so on.

Such requests are fairly hard for Swift to process. Consider a Range
header that asks for the first byte of every 10th MiB in a 4 GiB
object, but in some random order. That'll cause a lot of seeks on the
object server, but the corresponding response body is quite small in
comparison to the workload.

This commit makes Swift reject, with a 416 response, any ranged GET
request with more than fifty ranges, more than three overlapping
ranges, or more than eight non-increasing ranges.

This is a necessary prerequisite for supporting multi-range GETs on
large objects. Otherwise, a malicious user could construct a Range
header with hundreds of byte ranges where each individual byterange
requires the proxy to contact a different object server. If seeking
all over a disk is bad, connecting all over the cluster is way worse.

DocImpact

subject: Downgrade 'infinite' and 'unknown' capacity in weigher
commit_message:
Downgrade 'infinite' and 'unknown' capacity in weigher

When FilterScheduler was first introduced into Cinder, drivers were
required for the first time to report capacity. Some drivers preferred
to report 'infinite' or 'unknown' capacity because they were doing
thin-provisioning or the total capacity kept increasing. Now that we
have better support for thin-provisioning and we do find unrealistic
capacity couldn't do us any good in making optimal scheduling decision,
because 'infinite' and 'unknown' would always have the highest weight
when the weight multiplier is positive, which in most cases it is.

Drivers are expected to avoid sending 'infinite' 'unknown' capacity
anymore, instead, should report an actual real number for total/free
capacity.

This fix doesn't fix the driver, instead a small tweak is added to
CapacityWeigher in order to downgrade those drivers who report
'infinite' or 'unknown' as free capacity.  In particular, those who
report 'infinite'/'unknown' free capacity will be adjusted to be the
one has lowest weight, no matter in 'spreading' (weight multiplier>0)
or 'stacking' (weight multiplier<0) mode.

DocImpact

commit_message:
Remove restrictive hard-coded orders validation

The orders validation process for generating new secrets was enforcing
that parameters such as 'algorithm' were set to specific values, such
as 'aes'. This logic was put in place when only AES-generation was
provided by the default HSM plugin, as it is better to return a
synchronous error to clients than to wait until asynchronous
processing occurs. Now that 3rd party plugins are available that can
provide other generation types, this restriction is no longer valid.
So for Juno, the decision was to relax this validation logic, and to
let asynchronous processing by plugins flag any errors. In Kilo
however, the plan is to let the plugins perform this validation
up-front. TODO comments have been added to this effect.

commit_message:
Fix KeyError exception in NetApp CDOT iscsi driver volume create.

Prior to commit 98aa91b, when the NetApp CDOT iscsi driver experiences
an NaAPIError interacting with a backend vserver, it catches (and logs)
the NaAPIError, but then throws an irrelevant KeyError because the Path
metadata field has not been set properly.  The KeyError obfuscates and
buries the real error message.

In the cinder pools implementation via commit 98aa91b this problem no
longer exists, but there is a need for a fix in codebase (e.g. icehouse)
where cinder pools will not be implemented.

Note that there are multiple ways that an NaAPIError can be thrown.  In
launchpad bug 1363763 an NaAPIError was thrown, but then buried behind a
KeyError exception, because of an attempt to create a cinder volume with
a Netapp qos policy-group when the backend container on the filer
already itself had a qos policy-group attached to it (outside of

Update block_device_info to contain swap and ephemeral disks

An ephemeral or swap disk is attached to an instance on boot
as follows: nova boot --flavor FLAVOR --image IMAGE_ID
--swap 512 --ephemeral size=2 INSTANCE.  When a hard reboot is
performed on the instance, nova fails to recreate the
appropriate libvirt XML definition, containing the ephemeral
disk.  This is because the correct block_device_info dict that
is passed to the compute manager's reboot_instance method does
not contain swap or ephemeral disk key values that are necessary

block_device_info dict is also needed by nova rebuild, reboot,
resize, and migrate to recreate those disks.  This patch updates
_get_instance_volume_block_device_info (renamed

disk key values, in addition to the block_device_mapping it

problem. First, the rest of Congress uses eventlets instead
of threads. The DSE should follow what the rest of Congress
uses and also use eventlets. The fix for that problem is to
make the DSE use eventlets rather than threads. The second
problem is that threads are not very scalable in Python and
there is a lack of performance because of Python's GIL, which
only allows one thread to execute at a time. That is not
useful in the situation of the DSE since we want multiple
lines of code to execute at a time because multiple services
are running at once. The fix for that problem is also to
switch the DSE to using eventlets rather than threads.

The fix for these two problems, which this change does, is to
change the DSE to use eventlets rather than threads. Instead of
the d6service class inheriting from threading.Thread, it now
inherits from eventlet.greenthread.GreenThread, which makes d6service
now an eventlet rather than a thread. This will fix scalability
issues as I mentioned above, and also make the DSE use eventlets
like the rest of Congress does.

Changed the implementation so that the spawning of the green
threads is hidden from the user and they can initialize a
service by just using: Service() instead of having to use
deepsix.SpawnService(Service).

subject: Storage Policy defined constraints middleware
commit_message:
Storage Policy defined constraints middleware

Adding a constraints middleware that allows different
constraints rules per storage policy.

Currently, Swift allows only one set of object naming
and metadata rules per cluster. As new storage policies
are implemented, it is possible that different storage
back-ends have different set of rules on how objects
should be created for that specific storage system.

This patch attempts to refactor some of the default
object validation in PUT requests, so that the validation
happens early enough to quickly respond with errors, but
also adds the ability to new middlewares to define
their own constraints for a specific storage policy.

A mem_constraints middleware was added to serve as an
example where objects stored on an object mem_server
would have more strict naming rules (e.g., name length
max is 128).

A real-world example of where this constraints middleware
is necessary can be found on the SwiftOnFile project.
SwiftOnFile has different rules as objects name are mapped
to a POSIX filesystem directory structure.
Example: no names with double slashes or ending with
slashes are allowed.
SwiftOnFile constraints middleware: http://goo.gl/a96Icc

subject: labs: unregister clone VM disk, snapshots
commit_message:
labs: unregister clone VM disk, snapshots

Exporting via cloned VMs leaves the exported disks and snapshots
registered with VirtualBox (whether or not we pass a "--register" flag
to clonevm). Moving the exported VMs away or trying to export again to
the same location makes VirtualBox complain.

If we register the cloned VM upon creation and then unregister it
afterwards, we get at least rid of the snapshots and have only the
base disk left to unregister manually. This rather complicated method
is implemented here.

The export VMs have "-e" attached to their names, making them easier to
unregister here. They are also easy to recognize when imported into a
VirtualBox that already has node VMs using the original names.
